raw_text:
Pandas benefit from wireless net
 
 The world's dwindling panda population is getting a helping hand from a wireless internet network.
 
 The Wolong Nature Reserve in the Sichuan Province of southwest China is home to 20% of the remaining 1,500 giant pandas in the world. A broadband and wireless network installed on the reserve has allowed staff to chronicle the pandas' daily activities. The data and images can be shared with colleagues around the world. The reserve conducts vital research on both panda breeding and bamboo ecology.
 
 Using the network, vets have been able to observe how infant pandas feed and suggest changes to improve the tiny cubs' chances of survival.
 
 "Digital technology has transformed the way we communicate and share information inside Wolong and with the rest of the world," said Zhang Hemin, director of the Wolong Nature Reserve. "Our researchers now have state-of-the-art digital technology to help foster the panda population and manage our precious surroundings." The network has been developed by Intel, working closely with the staff at Wolong. It includes a 802.11b wireless network and a video monitoring system using five cameras to observe pandas around the clock.
 
 Before the new infrastructure arrived at the panda park, staff walked or drove to deliver floppy disks across the reserve. Infant panda health was recorded on paper notebooks and research teams in the field had little access to the data. To foster cultural links across the globe, a children's learning lab has been incorporated in the network, in collaboration with Globio (Federation for Global Biodiversity Education for Children), an international non-profit organisation. It will enable children at local primary schools to hook up with their peers in Portland, Oregon in the US. "Digital technology brings this story to life by enabling a global dialogue to help bridge cultures around the world," said Globio founder Gerry Ellis.
llama3.2:1b: The Wolong Nature Reserve in China has installed a wireless internet network that allows staff to monitor and share data about the giant pandas' daily activities, including feeding habits of infant cubs.
The network enables researchers to better manage the panda population and surroundings.
The reserve is working with Intel to develop the infrastructure, which includes a 802.11b wireless network and five cameras for video monitoring.

The network allows staff to share data and images with colleagues worldwide, improving research on breeding and bamboo ecology.
It also enabled veterinarians to monitor infant pandas' feeding habits and suggested improvements for their survival.
The network includes cameras and a children's learning lab that fosters global cultural connections among kids.

The network also includes a children's learning lab that allows children from various countries to connect and learn about pandas and global biodiversity.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Pandas in China's Wolong Nature Reserve benefit from a wireless internet network, which allows staff to share data with colleagues around the world.
The reserve houses 20% of the remaining 1,500 giant pandas.

tinyllama:1.1b: A panda population in China's Wolong Nature Reserve is getting a helping hand from a wireless internet network installed on the reserve.
The Wolong Nature Reserve, where 20% of the remaining giant pandas live, now has access to a broadband and wireless network that allows researchers to document the daily activities of the panda.

The data collected by the network can be shared with colleagues around the world, while the Wi-Fi system offers easier and faster communication for staff to share information on vital research work such as feeding, changes to baby cage layouts, and tracking of baby pandas in captivity.

The Wolong Nature Reserve has collaborated with global technology company Intel and partner organization Globio, which has developed a children's learning lab that allows children to connect with peers across the globe via wireless internet.
This initiative aims to foster cultural links and improve panda health by promoting digital communication in a remote nature reserve.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Pandas benefit from wireless internet networks.
Wolong Nature Reserve is home to an estimated 20% of the remaining giant pandas in the world.
The reserve maintains a broadband and wireless network that enables staff to chronicle the pandas' daily activities, providing valuable research data to scientists around the globe.
This technology has also enabled vets to observe how infants feed, suggesting improvements in breeding and survival rates.
Wolong Nature Reserve utilizes digital communication tools, such as floppy disks, to share information with other teams worldwide.

This wireless network enhances cultural connections between the pandas' home village and remote schools in Portland, Oregon, providing an interactive educational experience for both children at local primary schools and global researchers.

The network has also fostered cultural links, such as a children's learning lab in collaboration with Globio, an international non-profit organisation that allows local primary school students to connect with peers in the US.

A children's learning lab has been incorporated in the network, collaborating with an international non-profit organization, to enable children at local primary schools to connect with their peers in Portland, Oregon.

Vets have used data and images from the network to observe infant pandas, improving their survival chances.
The network was developed by Intel and includes a wireless network and video monitoring system, allowing staff to access research data from anywhere.
A children's learning lab has also been incorporated into the network as part of an effort to foster global communication and cultural links.

This technology allows staff to monitor and document panda activities, breeding, and bamboo ecology.
Vets can now observe infant pandas' feeding habits and suggest improvements for their survival.
The network, developed by Intel in collaboration with Wolong staff, comprises an 802.11b wireless system and five cameras for round-the-clock monitoring.
Before the network, researchers relied on physical media like floppy disks and paper notebooks, limiting data accessibility.
To foster global connections, a children's learning lab has been integrated into the network in partnership with Globio, enabling children in local schools to connect with peers in Portland, Oregon.
The project emphasizes bridging cultures through digital technology.

The reserve, home to 20% of the world's remaining giant pandas, uses broadband and wireless technology developed by Intel to support research on panda breeding and bamboo ecology.
The network enables vets to observe infant pandas and suggest improvements for their survival.
Previously, data sharing was slow and inefficient.
The system includes a wireless network, video monitoring, and a children's learning lab that connects local students with peers in the US, fostering global cultural exchange.
